source: Book - Inspired by 'Cracking the Coding Interview' (summarized and simplified)

level_1: They write code to build apps or websites.
SDEs work in companies like Google, Amazon, and Infosys.
They solve problems with logic and programming.
SDE is a good job for people who love technology.
level_2: SDEs use coding to solve real problems like online payments or chatting systems.
They work with teams to build big applications.
They follow steps like designing, writing, and testing software.
They often use tools like Git, GitHub, and code editors.
They work in teams using methods like Agile or Scrum.
level_3: Advanced SDEs design systems that many people use at once.
They build features in apps like login, search, or recommendations.
They think about how to make code fast and easy to maintain.
They review code from others and give feedback.
They also help solve performance and scaling problems.
level_4: Expert SDEs design complete systems like YouTube, Amazon backend, etc.
They decide how data will be stored and transferred efficiently.
They use cloud tools, testing frameworks, and monitor performance.
They lead small teams and help others grow technically.
They talk to product managers and take design decisions.

level_1: Making a calculator app for your phone.
Creating a program to keep track of marks.
level_2: Building an e-commerce website like Flipkart.
Creating a chatting app like WhatsApp.
Making a to-do list with save and delete features.
level_3: Creating backend for a food delivery app.
Working on login systems with OTP or email.
Building a search system for a large website.
level_4: Designing cloud-based systems like Google Drive.
Creating scalable services like payment gateways.
Handling millions of user requests in real-time systems.

level_1: IT services like TCS, Infosys hire beginner SDEs.
level_2: Product companies like Zomato, Paytm use SDEs for feature development.
level_3: Startups and MNCs need SDEs to scale products.
level_4: FAANG companies (Facebook, Amazon) hire expert SDEs for large-scale architecture.

level_1: Break big problems into small steps.
level_2: Use flowcharts to plan before writing code.
Check if there is a simpler way to solve the problem.
level_3: Think about time and space usage of the code.
Imagine how code will work with 1000+ users.
level_4: Think about failures, backups, and security.
Design code that other developers can reuse.

level_1: Write a program to print your name.
level_2: Check if a number is even or odd.
level_3: Design a system to store user details and retrieve them.
Write login system logic using email and password.
level_4: Design backend for a messaging system.
Create a caching system for faster access.

level_1: Don't copy code without understanding it.
level_2: Avoid writing too long code in one file.
Always test your code with different inputs.
level_4: Don't skip documentation for big projects.
Avoid optimizing too early-focus on clarity first.
